nodes.bodyText: Generic utility should be in utility class (if one doesn't exist already).
I'm pretty sure that Utils.readIntString already does the same thing as this method.
Any reason this can't live in the azure subpackage?
Also, please document that it is based on Cosmos change feed.
Let's call it CosmosChangeFeedToken? We can change the legacy token name to CosmosTimestampToken
I have refactored the code around this, and have changed some names. Let me know if you want the  name change with the code as well.
hashcode method won't do much unless you also override equals(Object) method.
Do we need a separate class for this?

I find this class confusing, especially this getter method.  It definitely feels like a cache, so maybe the class name should say so.  (I saw you mentioned it in the javadoc.) I originally thought this class would be used to actually run the change feed queries as opposed to delegating that to the data accessor and holding the results.

I have renamed this to CosmosChangeFeedCache.
The reason I have delegated query to CosmosDataAccessor is that I want to keep all the calls to cosmos apis at one place.
The last 3-4 lines have a lot of duplicate code, please simplify it.
Don't you have an equals method that does the same check?
this is not exactly same as equals, as it can have a different index. Semantically this is a different test than equals. It tests that the cache is still valid for the change feed token in request.
Use Utils.serializeString for all of the size prefixed string type things here. It handles edge cases around character encodings.
Maybe implement the general Object.equals method? You just need to add null handling and type checking to this method.
Minor: in azure -> using Cosmos change feed.
Minor: no need to store this in class, just return it in getType methods.
Can call the second constructor passing default version.
Why is this needed in addition to getType()?
Looks like the file needs formatting?

nodes.bodyText: Thinking out loud, wondering if we can return a pair struct holding new FindToken and entries list, rather than requiring caller to supply an empty non-null list.  (I wish Java had python's multivariate returns.)

+package com.github.ambry.cloud.azure;
+
+import com.github.ambry.cloud.CloudBlobMetadata;
+import com.github.ambry.replication.FindToken;
+import com.microsoft.azure.cosmosdb.DocumentClientException;
+import java.util.List;
+
+
+/**
+ * The replication feed that provides next list of blobs to replicate from azure, and a bookmark in form of {@link FindToken}.
+ */
+public interface AzureReplicationFeed {
+
+  /**
+   * Populate the next set of {@link CloudBlobMetadata} objects in {@code nextEntries} of specified partition {@code partitionPath}
+   * from the specified {@link FindToken} such that total size of all blobs in the entries are less or equal to {@code maxTotalSizeOfEntries}.
+   * This method should return at least one blob, if exists, after {@code curfindToken}, irrespective of {@code maxTotalSizeOfEntries} requirement.
+   * @param curfindToken current {@link FindToken} object that acts as a bookmark to return blobs after.
+   * @param nextEntries {@link List} to populate next {@link CloudBlobMetadata} objects in.
+   * @param maxTotalSizeOfEntries max total size of all the {@link CloudBlobMetadata} objects returned.
+   * @param partitionPath partition of the blobs.
+   * @return Updated {@link FindToken} object which can act as a bookmark for subsequent requests.
+   */
+  FindToken getNextEntriesAndUpdatedToken(FindToken curfindToken, List<CloudBlobMetadata> nextEntries,

nodes.bodyText: add javadoc comment that map is keyed by partitionId
Is it necessary to check all the members?  I thought the requestId guaranteed it was from the same consumer.

If you are handling the case where partition assignment "bounces back" to a VCR node, then mention that in a comment.  But I would prefer to remove the cache entry when a partition is unassigned (if that is feasible).

Partition being unassigned notification comes from helix. Propagating that notification all the way to this cache seems like an overkill to me. For now since we do not have a need to propagate that to azure destination classes, I want to avoid that and keep things simple.

Please read changeFeedCache.get(partitionId).getFetchedEntries() into fetchedEntries list up front and reuse.
Then you also won't need the cacheEmpty method since you can just check fetchedEntries.isEmpty().
We shouldn't need to generate a new requestid on every call.  Can reuse the previous one if not first time.
Minor: I would pass cosmosDataAccessor, azureMetrics here explicitly rather than relying on constructor to initialize them beforehand.
Objects.equals(str1, str2) does the same thing, no?
Right.. Initially I was sure that java has something for this, but just couldn't figure out this.
Sorry, I don't quite understand where nextEntries comes from.
nvm, I figure out what it means by reading AzureReplicationFeed interface.
minor: returns FindResult which contains both blob metadata and updated FindToken

nodes.bodyText: CACHE_VALID_DURATION_IN_MS seems to be a little better.
I wonder why we choose CACHE_INVALIDATION_DURATION_IN_MILLIS as initial delay. Can we use a random initial delay?

Because there is not point in using anything less than this period. If this thread gets scheduled before CACHE_INVALIDATION_DURATION_IN_MILLIS, there will be no items older than CACHE_INVALIDATION_DURATION_IN_MILLIS in the cache, and hence there will be nothing to invalidate. Only after CACHE_INVALIDATION_DURATION_IN_MILLIS there can be anything old enough to return  entry.getValue().isExpired() as true, to potentially become a candidate for invalidation.
could you explain why here is 5 * Integer.BYTES ?

3 integers are needed to store length of startContinuationToken, endContinuationToken and cacheSessionId.
2 integers are need for index and totalItems fields.
I don't see much benefit to the inner method.  We can roll that into this one.

nodes.bodyText: Please be consistent on using getters (getVersion()) vs straight reference (index, totalItems).  I prefer the latter.
Minor: can simply say "return new CosmosChangeFeedFindToken(...);
Minor: inconsistency where in some places you say Utils.method1() and others you say method2() making use of static import.  Please be consistent.
This will probably work for us, but if someone passed a high enough maxFeedSize to result in multiple feed pages, single() will throw an exception.  Maybe put a TODO/FIXME comment for now.
added a FIXME. Create a ticket https://jira01.corp.linkedin.com:8443/browse/AMBRY-6817 to track this. This ticket is part of Ambry Blueshift EPIC and added to backlog.
Rather than casting in every line, cast once to cosmosFindToken and reuse.
It seems overkill to run every test with both feed types when only one test depends on it.  Please remove and make the two below findEntriesSince methods public.
Same comment as in unit test: only testFindEntriesSince() really needs this and other tests can be time consuming.
I think it wouldn't be too bad to have parameterization in this class, as FindTokenHelper.getFindTokenFactoryFromReplicaType() also sort of gets tested here.
The else clause has no test coverage.
Because of this override, CosmosDataAccessor.queryChangeFeed() has no test coverage.
created tests for CosmosDataAccessor.queryChangeFeed() in CosmosDataAccessorTest.java
Method has no test coverage.  Can you add test case to CosmosDataAccessorTest?

-   * @param partitionId Partition for which change feed entries have to be returned.
-   * @return updated {@link CosmosChangeFeedFindToken} after processing the next set of entries.
-   */
-  private CosmosChangeFeedFindToken getNextEntriesAndToken(CosmosChangeFeedFindToken cosmosChangeFeedFindToken,
-      List<CloudBlobMetadata> results, long maxEntriesSize, String partitionId) throws DocumentClientException {
+   * @param curFindToken {@link FindToken} after which the next entries have to be returned.
+   * @param maxTotalSizeOfEntries maximum size of all the blobs returned.
+   * @param partitionPath Partition for which change feed entries have to be returned.
+   * @return {@link FindResult} instance that contains updated {@link FindToken} object which can act as a bookmark for
+   * subsequent requests, and {@link List} of {@link CloudBlobMetadata} entries.
+   * @throws {@link DocumentClientException}.
+   */ public FindResult getNextEntriesAndUpdatedToken(FindToken curFindToken, long maxTotalSizeOfEntries,

nodes.bodyText: Need Test annotation in these two methods?
this class can be static, since it doesn't use any fields from the outer class
make upper case if this is meant to be a constant

Since you are not using daemon threads and the executor is not shutdown, this may block the jvm process from ending in some cases.
The server/vcr does have a shared scheduler that could be passed into here, if its not too cumbersome to get it all the way here. Alternatively you could make ReplicationFeed closable and shutdown the ExecutorService yourself.

if the populateChangeFeedCache methods returned the CacheEntry objects they added, you could get rid of a lot of the duplicate get calls to the cache in getNextEntriesAndUpdatedToken. It also may help to avoid some edge cases where the background cache eviction thread could remove items from the cache while the getNextEntriesAndUpdatedToken is executing (causing NPEs).

Instead of constructing an intermediate list you could also:
feedResponse.getResults().stream().map(doc -> createMetadataFromDocument(doc)).forEach(changeFeed::add)
to address this, could you use toIterable() and have this method return Iterable<FeedResponse<Document>>?

I have a ticket filed for this here -- https://jira01.corp.linkedin.com:8443/browse/AMBRY-6817 (added to backlog and blueshift epic and assigned to me).
Will fix this with this ticket. Have added this note in the ticket.
Is the close called from anywhere?
